TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: aitsu uri pasemalaw aken tua sikazepzepan nua maretseketsekeł a mamazangiłan.
aico ori pasemalaw aken toa sikazepzepan noa marecekecekelj a mamazangiljan.
S.TRANSL: Now I am going to tell you about the discussions of chiefly families who are planning to arrange a marriage.

S.FORM: aitsu nu izua uri marepaukuukuz nua mamazangiłan, azua sauqałay mangtjez a sema zua itua savavayan; sa patsun tazua sauzayan a uri sinisusu tua zua vavayan, sa kazepzep tuki marasudj tuki ini.
aico no izoa ori marepaokookoz noa mamazangiljan, azoa saoqaljay mangtjez a sema zoa itoa savavayan; sa pacon tazoa saozayan a ori sinisoso toa zoa vavayan, sa kazepzep toki marasodj toki ini.
S.TRANSL: When chiefly families are going to have a betrothal the man’s family come to the woman’s place; and they (the bride’s family) look at the possessions which are to be given as a bride price for the woman, and they discuss whether they can agree or not.

S.FORM: nu inika marasudj magagulagula tua maretseketsekeł.
no inika marasodj magagolagola toa marecekecekelj.
S.TRANSL: If they don’t agree the marriage cannot go forward.

S.FORM: łakua nu marasudj tjara marepaukuukuz anga tiamadju.
ljakoa no marasodj tjara marepaokookoz anga tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: But if they agree they certainly are betrothed.

S.FORM: qau aitsu uri qivu anga ken tua kapatatevelavela niamadju.
qao aico ori qivo anga ken toa kapatatevelavela niamadjo.
S.TRANSL: So now I’ll tell you the dialogue between them.

S.FORM: maitutsu a savavayan: pai aitsu a timun a nia kaka a nia vetjek, uri putakalanan aken.
maitoco a savavayan: pai aico a timon a nia kaka a nia vetjek, ori potakalanan aken.
S.TRANSL: This is what the woman’s side say: Now our brothers and sisters I have something to say.

S.FORM: aku ika tjen a maleva, aku ika tjen a seman azua tua mareka tja kaka tua mareka tja sikataqałan a nakemasi tjuqała.
ako ika tjen a maleva, ako ika tjen a seman azoa toa mareka tja kaka toa mareka tja sikataqaljan a nakemasi tjoqalja.
S.TRANSL: Why shouldn’t we be glad and praise one another as siblings and fellow-tribespeople from elsewhere?

S.FORM: małimałi a nasałinga mun a nakiłivak mun nalitjengits(?) mun kaumaya tua nu ałak tua nu vuvu.
maljimalji a nasaljinga mon a nakiljivak mon nalitjengic(?) mon kaomaya toa no aljak toa no vovo.
S.TRANSL: We are grateful that you want, love and perhaps(?) your child or grandchild.

S.FORM: łakua pai aitsu a nu sinipaqayam aitsu a nu kinuletj a nu linanaw tu kiłivak tua nu ałak tua nu vuvu, aku inika uri tsengtseng, aku inika uri nanguaq a tja sipalungulungu nua mareka kaka a marevetjevetjek, aya sa ku kininemneman.

ljakoa pai aico a no sinipaqayam aico a no kinoletj a no linanaw to kiljivak toa no aljak toa no vovo, ako inika ori cengceng, ako inika ori nangoaq a tja sipalongolongo noa mareka kaka a marevetjevetjek, aya sa ko kininemneman.
S.TRANSL: But what you have set out, what you have provided as an expression(?) of your love for your child or grandchild, why isn’t it suitable, why isn’t it up to what we expect(?) of our brothers and sisters?, is what I am thinking.

S.FORM: sauqałay: ui tjara maitazua, uła namaya aya men.
saoqaljay: oi tjara maitazoa, olja namaya aya men.
S.TRANSL: Man’s side: Yes, that’s true. We want the same.

S.FORM: nia kinłang tu inika napenapadjulu, tu inika uri nu siselaing a nia vusam a nia tjałayan.
nia kinljang to inika napenapadjolo, to inika ori no siselaing a nia vosam a nia tjaljayan.
S.TRANSL: We know that it looks as if it’s not properly prepared, that it wouldn’t be acceptable to you our original roots.

S.FORM: łakua qau saka nu aya itjen.
ljakoa qao saka no aya itjen.
S.TRANSL: But then what are we to do?

S.FORM: pai małi ki tsadja i inuan a nu, a kinitjuayan a kiniłałaungan nua nu ałak nua nu vuvu uta, nu kełangen uta tu nasemalimsim, nu kełangen uta tu napenapeqauqaung uta aravats; saka kiłałava mun saka pakadjele mun a maya numa.

pai malji ki cadja i inoan a no, a kinitjoayan a kiniljaljaongan noa no aljak noa no vovo ota, no keljangen ota to nasemalimsim, no keljangen ota to napenapeqaoqaong ota aravac; saka kiljaljava mon saka pakadjele mon a maya noma.
S.TRANSL: It would be different if the possessions and abodes of your children and grandchildren were a long way away. You know too that we are badly off, you know that we are very pitiable too; and you were waiting for us and you seem to belittle(?) us.

S.FORM: qau mere anemanga men uta a nu ałak a nu vuvu; nu aitutsuin uta aravats a paqaung aravats.
qao mere anemanga men ota a no aljak a no vovo; no aitocoin ota aravac a paqaong aravac.
S.TRANSL: So what are we to become, we your children and grandchildren? You treat us like this and cause us a lot of pain.

S.FORM: savavayan: ui ma, tjara maitazua.
savavayan: oi ma, tjara maitazoa.
S.TRANSL: Woman’s side: Well yes, it’s like that.

S.FORM: nia kełangen a maitazua łakua, pai aitsu a nu varung uta a nu kininemneman uta nia, a mareka nia kaka sauqałay, inika nu sinipaquliqulidan aravats kaumaya ta nu kininemneman.
nia keljangen a maitazoa ljakoa, pai aico a no varong ota a no kininemneman ota nia, a mareka nia kaka saoqaljay, inika no sinipaqoliqolidan aravac kaomaya ta no kininemneman.
S.TRANSL: We know it’s like that; but, brothers and sisters of the man’s side, your hearts and thoughts, you have not been truly honest in your thoughts.

S.FORM: pai aitsu nu kana nu nalemanaw(?) mun, nuka nu pinaquliqulidanen a nu kininemneman, uzi ki kana nu pinarumaya, łakua ayatua namatsaquan mun a kinemnem, tutsu anga małian anga tja kakudan, inika tjen a kematsukatsu tua sitiavan tua sikatjeluan a tja kakudan.

pai aico no kana no nalemanaw(?) mon, noka no pinaqoliqolidanen a no kininemneman, ozi ki kana no pinaromaya, ljakoa ayatoa namacaqoan mon a kinemnem, toco anga maljian anga tja kakodan, inika tjen a kemacokaco toa sitiavan toa sikatjeloan a tja kakodan.
S.TRANSL: Well if you had ?, if you had been honest in your thinking, you would have ?. But because you are clever at thinking, (you say) now the customs have changed, we don’t keep on the customs of yesterday and the day before.

S.FORM: aitsu a izuanga tja kivadaqan a ḍipung a imaza i kungkuan.
aico a izoanga tja kivadaqan a dripong a imaza i kongkoan.
S.TRANSL: Now there are the Japanese here in the police station to ask.

S.FORM: ki tja paligiligiłi anga, ki tja katsaqu-i anga a qivu tiamadju, sa tje palaluqeluqemi, aya nu varung.
ki tja paligiligilji anga, ki tja kacaqo-i anga a qivo tiamadjo, sa tje palaloqeloqemi, aya no varong.
S.TRANSL: We’ll deceive them, we’ll talk cleverly to them and we’ll get the better of them, is what you’re saying in your hearts.

S.FORM: łakua pai aitsu a nu vuvu aitsu a nu ałak palisi a nu katsaquin, palisi a nu kaligiłen a qivu.
ljakoa pai aico a no vovo aico a no aljak palisi a no kacaqoin, palisi a no kaligiljen a qivo.
S.TRANSL: But it’s taboo to fool your grandchild or child, it’s taboo to deceive her in words.

S.FORM: nu namaitazua a nu varung, neka, ika tjen a sa malalaing angata.
no namaitazoa a no varong, neka, ika tjen a sa malalaing angata.
S.TRANSL: If that’s the way your hearts are, that’s it, we certainly won’t agree.

S.FORM: sauqałay: paḍia mun paḍia mun a nia vusam a mareka nia kaka.
saoqaljay: padria mon padria mon a nia vosam a mareka nia kaka.
S.TRANSL: Man’s side: You are quite right, quite right, brothers and sisters who are our roots.

S.FORM: łakua pai mereanemanga uta nu ałak a nu kaka.
ljakoa pai mereanemanga ota no aljak a no kaka.
S.TRANSL: But what are we to become, your children and your brothers and sisters?

S.FORM: pai titjen a tsautsau anga kasałinga-i kipakimi tua mana tsekeł nua tja ałak, nu aya itjen a timaimanga, tjara napapułat itjen tjara nakinemnem itjen tua mana uri napenapadjulu, nu mateveteveł uta tjara liaw aravats a kai, tjara łakua, qau saka nema tja alapen, pakasinu itjen nu masa uraman nu masa sinalimsiman.

pai titjen a caocao anga kasaljinga-i kipakimi toa mana cekelj noa tja aljak, no aya itjen a timaimanga, tjara napapoljat itjen tjara nakinemnem itjen toa mana ori napenapadjolo, no matevetevelj ota tjara liaw aravac a kai, tjara ljakoa, qao saka nema tja alapen, pakasino itjen no masa oraman no masa sinalimsiman.
S.TRANSL: All of us human beings when anyone of us says that we want and are looking for a spouse for our child, we certainly do our best, we certainly think of what will be proper provision. But what are we to take, what way are we to take because of our need and our pitiable state?

S.FORM: pai aitsu a nu ałak a nu vuvu mana sika namaitutsu, aitsu kinamiaminan anga pinapułatan anga.
pai aico a no aljak a no vovo mana sika namaitoco, aico kinamiaminan anga pinapoljatan anga.
S.TRANSL: And that’s the way it is with your child or grandchild. We have got to the end of everything, we have done everything for him.

S.FORM: łakua tjara nu pakadjelein.
ljakoa tjara no pakadjelein.
S.TRANSL: But you just despise (?) it.

S.FORM: łakua qadjaw nimun uta.
ljakoa qadjaw nimon ota.
S.TRANSL: But it’s up to you,

S.FORM: nu ika saqetju a nu varung, nu ika mun a salełseł uta tua nu ałak, timun a mareka a tia kama a tia kina.
no ika saqetjo a no varong, no ika mon a saleljselj ota toa no aljak, timon a mareka a tia kama a tia kina.
S.TRANSL: if your hearts aren’t sad, if you don’t have pity on your child, our fathers and mothers.

S.FORM: savavayan: maitazua łakua uri mezangal sa ku kai.
savavayan: maitazoa ljakoa ori mezangal sa ko kai.
S.TRANSL: Woman’s side: That’s so; but I’m going to go on speaking.

S.FORM: pai kana sa kudanga kana kamatsulen tua sitsuayan tua sitiavan tua sikatjeluan.
pai kana sa kodanga kana kamacolen toa sicoayan toa sitiavan toa sikatjeloan.
S.TRANSL: (?) How would it be if we followed the customs of long ago, of yesterday and the day before.

S.FORM: pai katiaw kasikatjelu na tja pinakakaizuazua a tja pinakakudakudanga nu mareka sałingałinga itjen a mareka kaka a marevetjevetjek a tjara kavusavusaman.
pai katiaw kasikatjelo na tja pinakakaizoazoa a tja pinakakodakodanga no mareka saljingaljinga itjen a mareka kaka a marevetjevetjek a tjara kavosavosaman.
S.TRANSL: Well yesterday and the day before (?) there were all sorts of things we had to give and do if we wanted one another, we brothers and sisters of the real chiefly families.

S.FORM: łakua pai tutsu malumay anga, izuanga tja kivadaqan izua pazazekazekatj tjanuitjen numa.
ljakoa pai toco malomay anga, izoanga tja kivadaqan izoa pazazekazekatj tjanoitjen noma.
S.TRANSL: But now we have gone weak(?). There are people to ask. There are people who give us orders.

S.FORM: aku mun a setseleł a maya, aku mun a seman paravats aravats numa?
ako mon a secelelj a maya, ako mon a seman paravac aravac noma?
S.TRANSL: Why are you so cold(?)? Why do you flatter(?) so much?

S.FORM: saka qadjaw nimun.
saka qadjaw nimon.
S.TRANSL: And it’s up to you.

S.FORM: pai tutsu tja minadjeledjele anga sa kininemneman.
pai toco tja minadjeledjele anga sa kininemneman.
S.TRANSL: And now we have all cut down our ideas(?).

S.FORM: łakua ika mun a masan itał ika mun a masan musał tua nu kininemneman tua nu sinipaqayam.
ljakoa ika mon a masan italj ika mon a masan mosalj toa no kininemneman toa no sinipaqayam.
S.TRANSL: But you haven’t thought once or twice (?) about what you have put on show.

S.FORM: pai aitsu a keḍikeḍi inika matsidił inika maḍusa matjałałak, tjuruvu aravats a matjałałak.
pai aico a kedrikedri inika macidilj inika madrosa matjaljaljak, tjorovo aravac a matjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: This child hasn’t got just one or just two parents; there are very many people (of the parents’ generation)(?).

S.FORM: nu mavadavaday semainu tunazuanga tjara tja nemayain anga nu qempuqepu, tja nemayain anga nu qivu.
no mavadavaday semaino tonazoanga tjara tja nemayain anga no qempoqepo, tja nemayain anga no qivo.
S.TRANSL: If they all go off everywhere, what are we to say to call them together again?

S.FORM: nu mateveteveł uta tjara liaw aravats a kai, tjara vutselay(?) itjen sakamaya.
no matevetevelj ota tjara liaw aravac a kai, tjara vocelay(?) itjen sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: If they are together again, there will be a great deal of talk; we’ll all be pale with shame(?).

S.FORM: saka qadjaw nimun, nu ika mun sa maumał anga nu kininemneman, kitjen a maḍaḍikiḍikitj sakamaya.
saka qadjaw nimon, no ika mon sa maomalj anga no kininemneman, kitjen a madradrikidrikitj sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: So it’s up to you. If you don’t change your thinking we’ll cut the meeting short.

S.FORM: tjara nasemalimsim mun sakamaya.
tjara nasemalimsim mon sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: You are certainly pitiable.

S.FORM: vutselay itjen tua matjałałak nu sa nu vuvu nu sa nu ałak.
vocelay itjen toa matjaljaljak no sa no vovo no sa no aljak.
S.TRANSL: We are pale with shame before the parents of this your grandchild or child.

S.FORM: sauqałay: ui ui, łakua nakuya uta mezangal aravats.
saoqaljay: oi oi, ljakoa nakoya ota mezangal aravac.
S.TRANSL: Man’s side: Yes, yes. But it’s bad to go on too much.

S.FORM: uła men anemaya-i aya men.
olja men anemaya-i aya men.
S.TRANSL: What can be said to us, we ask ourselves.

S.FORM: tjara paquliqulid mun nu pasaqetju mun nu mełel mun nu kisan kuya mun tusa nia kininemneman tusa separutan tusa ika napenapadjulu, łakua aitsu ki nu(?) sipazekatj sakamaya, ki kamseng a nu pinalangedan anga men ta nu varung ta nu kininemneman.

tjara paqoliqolid mon no pasaqetjo mon no meljel mon no kisan koya mon tosa nia kininemneman tosa separotan tosa ika napenapadjolo, ljakoa aico ki no(?) sipazekatj sakamaya, ki kamseng a no pinalangedan anga men ta no varong ta no kininemneman.
S.TRANSL: You are quite right when you are harsh with us, when you ? us, when you object to our thinking, to our weakness, to the unsuitability of our provision(?). But you could forgive this(?). It would be enough that you have let us know your feelings and thinking.

S.FORM: manu tiamen uta uła tja patjavavavi uła tjen a madjadjelidjeli, aya uta nia kininemneman tiamen a sauqałay.
mano tiamen ota olja tja patjavavavi olja tjen a madjadjelidjeli, aya ota nia kininemneman tiamen a saoqaljay.
S.TRANSL: We too on the man’s side we want us all to make progress, so that we can all be happy together, that’s our thinking too.

S.FORM: łakua saka nu aya itjen a naseparut amen aravats.
ljakoa saka no aya itjen a naseparot amen aravac.
S.TRANSL: But what are we to do, as we are so very weak?

S.FORM: qau saka mereanemanga men uta.
qao saka mereanemanga men ota.
S.TRANSL: And what are we to become too?

S.FORM: qau ika mun a sa salimsim uta tua nu ałak tua nu vuvu, papaula-u(?) amen uta.
qao ika mon a sa salimsim ota toa no aljak toa no vovo, papaola-o(?) amen ota.
S.TRANSL: You don’t take pity either on your child or grandchild. Take pity on us too.

S.FORM: savavayan: ui łakua maitazua mun a palalaut tua nu kai, łakua ini, tjara kuḍesul amen sakamaya.
savavayan: oi ljakoa maitazoa mon a palalaot toa no kai, ljakoa ini, tjara kodresol amen sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: Woman’s side: Yes, but you keep saying that. But no, we will just stand firm.

S.FORM: aitsu a tja sipatataretarev a kavusaman kadjunangan pana qałuqałupen vadis, mana tja sipatataretarev numa.
aico a tja sipatataretarev a kavosaman kadjonangan pana qaljoqaljopen vadis, mana tja sipatataretarev noma.
S.TRANSL: The bride prices of us real chiefs are land, rivers, hunting grounds, meat tribute, those are our bride prices.

S.FORM: ku pai papatsuni anan amen tua kadjunangan tua pana tua qałuqałupen tua vadis, sana tje karasurasudj sana tje pałałungułungu sana tja qaqivuivu-i a mareka tja kaka a inu tunazuanga a mapułat, sana tje, sana tja parepaukuukuz, aya sa kininemneman numa.

ko pai papaconi anan amen toa kadjonangan toa pana toa qaljoqaljopen toa vadis, sana tje karasorasodj sana tje paljaljongoljongo sana tja qaqivoivo-i a mareka tja kaka a ino tonazoanga a mapoljat, sana tje, sana tja parepaokookoz, aya sa kininemneman noma.
S.TRANSL: So then show us land, rivers, hunting grounds, meat tribute and we’ll all agree, and we’ll put them side by side, and we’ll tell all our brothers and sisters everywhere, and we’ll-and we’ll have a betrothal, is what we think.

S.FORM: ini nu aya mun, ki tjen a maḍaḍikiḍikitj sakamaya.
ini no aya mon, ki tjen a madradrikidrikitj sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: If you say no, we’ll just cut the talk short.

S.FORM: nu uri puałak tiamadju, nu uri tinveteveł a zinkatj nua naqemati, kitjen a maumaumał anga nu tjaivilił a mazepzep numa.
no ori poaljak tiamadjo, no ori tinvetevelj a zinkatj noa naqemati, kitjen a maomaomalj anga no tjaivililj a mazepzep noma.
S.TRANSL: If they are to have children, if what the creator has provided is to be brought together, we’ll renew the discussion in the future.

S.FORM: aitsu a tja zepzepan tutsu a qezemezemetj tjara qemulip sakamaya.
aico a tja zepzepan toco a qezemezemetj tjara qemolip sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: Our discussion tonight is just a waste of time.

S.FORM: sa patjezuanga sa tja zepzepan.
sa patjezoanga sa tja zepzepan.
S.TRANSL: So that’s the end of our discussion.
